title: [Masters Project]: Accelerating XD-GRASP MRI Reconstruction
subtitle: For my thesis, I made use of an FPGA and GPU to accelerate MRI reconstruction
company: Imperial College London in collaboration with the Institute of Cancer Research
description: Cancer is a horrible illness and the treatment for it can last a long time, meaning the patient must endure the turmoil and stress for months.
Adaptive radiotherapy aims to reduce the treatment time for radiotherapy (one type of cancer therapy) by accelerating its processes to be real-time.
I used an FPGA and GPU to reduce the time taken for 4D MRI reconstruction, with the fourth dimension being in time, using a pre-existing algorithm: XD-GRASP.

In addition to a proposed XD-GRASP implementation, I explored the requirements for bridging the gap between the reconstruction time I achieved (around 24 minutes for the specific data dimensions) and real-time reconstruction.

title: ABSA: Aspect Based Sentiment Analysis
subtitle: Building relationships between entities in the world with the aim of aggregating sentiment between them
company: Imperial College London in collaboration with Goldman Sachs
description: With the large amount of qualitative data available to investment funds, it is useful to have a quick way to summarise documents.

This project aimed to build weighted relationships between non-named entities (such as a link between 'camera' and 'phone'), named-entities (such as 'Apple' and 'Tim Cook') and between named and non-named entities (such as 'iPhone' and 'camera').

Using these relationships, the sentiment associated with each entity, scored between -1 and 1, could be aggregated following a hierarchical structure - for example, propagating the sentiment of the iPhone to Apple.
To achieve this we developed training and pruning algorithms to reduce our data into an entity relationships graph.

title: MatchUps
subtitle: A web application for organising amateur sports
description: For the second year WebApps project at ICL, my team and I created an application to help people organise amateur sports matches.

Users registered a team with their friends and used the application to find potential opponents in their surrounding area. This application made it easy to organise matches by providing a live-chat option and allowed teams to track their results.

title: TRON
subtitle: A re-implementation of the classic TRON game with an AI opponent
description: During Summer 2017, I reimplemented the code written by my team and I during the end-of-term project in my first year at ICL.

This game was playable by up to 2 human players and thousands of AI players (CPU forbidding). We used this opportunity to try and write intelligent opponents which would simulate moves ahead and use a scoring system to know how to act.

In the end, this turned out to be overkill for the task at hand and we found that an opponent which followed a greedy-like approach (try to find the most open space) worked best and became unbeatable by any human player.
The image shows the final result after running a game with 100 AI opponents - what some might call 'modern art'.
